author: andschwa
body:
- [x] Resolves #954
- [ ] Still need tests
- [ ] Need to update known issues
- [x] Need to fix globbing to have unix semantics:
  - [x] expand hidden (.dotfile) directories
  - [x] return relative (not absolute) paths
- [ ] Need to file issue about escape characters

Enable path globbing for native commands.

E.g. `ls *.md` expands to `ls /path/to/README.md /path/to/CHANGELOG.md`

If expansion fails, the argument is sent literally, so `ls foo*` results in `/usr/bin/ls: cannot access foo*: No such file or directory`.

Don't glob expand if the verbatim marker was used. So `ls --% *` fails with `/bin/ls: cannot access '*': No such file or directory`

Same caveats as #1639; but the code is enabled only on *nix platforms, and the failing test is fixed.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Jeffery's great. The problem with `ls .git*` and other `.dotfiles` is that the globbing semantics by default ignore hidden directories. This isn't a problem with `Get-ChildItem` because it can be passed `-Hidden`; but for globbing on *nix, I'll add a set of semantics to the globber to include hidden files (and return relative instead of absolute paths).

Per [commitie decision](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-RFC/blob/48f23e86b836dfe25ff3dd76733fc1dfb32e0e1f/X-Rejected/RFC0009-Glob-for-Native-Tools.md#majority-decision) we should revisit this work item.

@lzybkr proposed an implementation that would just call `glob(3)` lib function. From glancing at the current version of the code, it seems that it could modified to this with minimal changes. All changes would be localized in native command binder.
